All Chargeability: All countries which are not those specifically listed in the visa bulletin.
Employment-based: Bringing immigrants in to work within the United States. Some of these are short-term while some are long-term. Immigrants require a sponsor for this.
Family-based: Bringing family to the United States. With the exception of one preference, this is United States Citizens bringing close immigrant relatives to the United States.
Visa Bulletin
Preference: Because the United States works on a quota system, preferences are used to dictate how many of a certain class of immigrant is allowed into the country.
Processing Date: This is the date for which applications are being processed. Think of it as how far back the backlog is for the visa program.

Visa Bulletin: A publication on immigration in the United States which details which immigration visas are being processed depending on a variety of factors. You can think of this as a waiting list for immigrants.

Consulate: These provide valuable services to travelers. While the phone numbers included in this app are to US consulates, most countries have their own consulates throughout the world to assist their own citizens.
Currency: The local currency used and accepted.
Country Information

Language: The common language spoken in the country. This is not exclusive, and many other languages may be spoken within the country. The ones included are often de facto languages or official languages.
Nationality (adj): The nationality of the people of the country. The nationality provided is the adjective form.

Constitution: The United State Constitution. The founding document of the United States. This document lays out how the US government functions as well as the rights of those within the United States. It is included as everyone traveling to or from the United States should at least have it available to them.

UDHR: The Universal Declaration of Human Rights. While not legally binding on its own, this document lays out the basic human rights every human being holds and is the basis for some customary international law. It is included as everyone should have access to and know their human rights.
Documents

VCCR: The Vienna Convention on Consular Relations. While most of the document is not helpful to most travelers, Article 36 allows a traveler to request that their consulate be notified of their arrest if they so choose so long as the countries are a party to the VCCR. The full text is included for completeness.

Business: Short-term business trips. These will often involve traveling for a meeting, negotiating a contract, settling an estate, or meeting with business partners. If you plan on earning an income from the destination country, do not select this.
Destination Country: The country you are traveling to.
Country of Origin: The country you are traveling from.
Education: You plan on attending a school or university while you are traveling.
End date: The day you plan on returning to the country of origin.
Events and Trips
Event Name: A name to describe your trip so that you can easily remember it or pick it out among any other trips you plan.
Other: Your plans do not fit within the other categories. Common examples include but are not limited to: marriage, investment, acting as an informant, participating in a lawsuit.
Reason: The reason for the trip. It is important the correct category is chosen as many visa requirements depend on the type of trip being taken.
Destination State: Only shown and selected if the United States is selected as the destination. This is to specify which specific state you are traveling to.
State of Origin: Only shown and selected if the United States is selected as the country of origin. This is to specify which specific state you are leaving from.
Start date: The day you plan on leaving for the trip.
Tourism: Vacation. You will not be selling or making any money. You are simply traveling as a tourist.

Work: You plan to earn an income while in the country, often by selling goods in the destination country or working for someone while in the destination country. This can be temporary work or permanent work. The visa bulletin is available for the United States so you can check the processing date (see Visa Bulletin for definition) for employment-based immigration visas.
Federal Circuit: The federal circuit in which a state sits. Laws can change within the United States depending on which federal circuit a state sits. Of course, state laws vary from state to state.
State Information

Sanctuary Areas: These are areas within a non-sanctuary state whose local law enforcement may not ask about immigration status when responding to an emergency or arresting a suspect. Local laws will vary.

Sanctuary State: If a state is a sanctuary state, it generally means that local law enforcement for the entire state may not ask about immigration status when responding to an emergency or arresting a suspect. Local laws will vary.
Travel Advisory: Advisories put out by the United States Department of State (DOS) in order to warn travelers of potential problems. DOS has moved to a country specific 4 level system.
Code C: (Crime) Violent or organized crime is present in areas of the country. Law enforcement only be able to respond in a limited manner.
Code E: (Time-limited event) Short-term events that may pose safety risks. These may include elections, sporting events, political protests, or other incidents
Code H: (Health) Disease outbreaks, disruption of medical infrastructure, or other health related events pose a safety risk to travelers.
Code O: (Other) The catch-all category. Risks that do not fall into any other category go here.
Code T: (Terrorism) There has been a terrorist attack or there is a threat of terrorism or both.
Code U: (Civil Unrest) Instability may cause violence, disruptions, or safety risks.
Travel Advisories

Level 1: (Exercise normal precautions) The lowest level travel advisory. While there is some risk in any international travel, countries in this level pose the least risk and are generally safe to travel to.
Level 2: (Exercise increased caution) There is a heightened risk to safety and security due to any number of reasons.
Level 3: (Reconsider travel) There is a serious risk to safety and security. Travel should be avoided if possible.

Level 4: (Do not travel) Countries within this category pose greater risks of life-threatening events. Additionally, the United States may not be able to provide assistance in these countries, or only very limited assistance.
Entry Permit: Similar to a visa, but may have more restrictions or conditions. Permits may expire once you leave a country requiring you to pay for a new one upon reentry.
ESTA (Electronic System for Travel Authorization): An automated system to determine if travelers are eligible to enter the Untied States under the VWP.
Visa Requirements
No visa required: You may travel to this country without filling out and paying for a visa application or any of the other formal processes required of those that do require a visa.
Registration required: Travelers are required to register with the local police within a certain period of time after arrival, typically 24 hours.

Schengen Area: A zone in which travelers may freely travel between countries who are a part of this without a passport. These countries are: Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Italy, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, and Switzerland.
Vaccination required: An international certificate of vaccination is required to enter this country. This may be general, but oftentimes vaccination for specific diseases is required.
Visa: An endorsement that allows the holder to enter, leave, or stay in a country for a specified period of time. These are endorsed within a passport. They do not take the place of a passport.
Visa on Arrival: You may apply for a visa after you have arrived in the country, oftentimes in the port of entry.

Visa Waiver Program (VWP): The Visa Waiver program allows people from certain authorized countries to travel to the United States without the need for a visa if the trip is for tourism or business. Travelers must still register for ESTA.
